data.title: Exeter College Chapel Choir, University of Oxford, England, to Perform at Williams College
data.meta_description: The Exeter College Chapel Choir, University of Oxford, England will perform at Williams College on Wednesday, Sept. 16, at 7:30 p.m. The performance will be held in Thompson Memorial Chapel on the Williams campus. It is free and the public is cordially invited to attend.
data.text:
Media contact: Noelle Lemoine, communications assistant; tele: (413) 597-4277; email: [email protected]

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 14, 2009 — The Exeter College Chapel Choir, University of Oxford, England will perform at Williams College on Wednesday, Sept. 16, at 7:30 p.m. The performance will be held in Thompson Memorial Chapel on the Williams campus. It is free and the public is cordially invited to attend.

The Exeter College choir is on a tour celebrating Exeter College Chapel’s 150th anniversary and the performance is part of the celebrations of the 25th anniversary of the Williams Exeter Program at Oxford University.

The choir, one of the finest mixed-voice choirs will present a programme of sacred choral music, much of it from England.

This rich Anglican tradition, founded particularly around the office of Evensong, has been in existence for over 500 years and is as vibrant as ever.

The choir are as at home in the music of Byrd, Tallis and their contemporaries as they are in the twentieth century tradition, whose exponents include Elgar, Howells and Parry, who was educated at Eton College, and also at Exeter College, Oxford.

Contemporary music is also featured in the choir’s repertoire; the choir also enjoys singing lighter numbers and a Capella arrangements of jazz standards and pop music.

Visiting Williams with the choir are also Frances Cairncross, rector of Exeter College; Rev. Dr. Helen Orchard, chaplain of Exeter College; and Katrina Hancock, director of development.

The event is sponsored by the Dean of Faculty’s Office.

Exeter College is one of the oldest colleges in the University of Oxford, founded in 1314. During its history, it has had many illustrious students, including J.R.R. Tolkien, author of “Lord of the Rings,” the artist William Morris and the athlete Roger Bannister. More recently, well-known literary figures that have studied here have included Martin Amis and Philip Pullman. It is also famous as the site of the death of Inspector Morse in the eponymous television series, which also featured Exeter College Chapel Choir in the same episode.

Williams College offers a yearlong program of studies at Oxford University in co-operation with Exeter College, one of the constituent colleges of the University. The Williams-Exeter Programme provides students with a unique opportunity to participate fully in the intellectual and social life of one of the world’s great universities.

Thomas Kohut, the Sue and Edgar Wachenheim III Professor of History at Williams, is the present director of the Williams-Exeter Programme at Oxford University. Previous directors include Daniel O’Connor, philosophy (1985-87); Jean-Bernard Bucky, theatre (1987-89); Robert Kavanaugh, psychology (1989-91); Andrew Crider, psychology (1991-93); John Reichert, English (1993-95); William Wagner, history (1995-97); Alan White, philosophy (1997-99); Jennifer Bloxam, music (1999-2001); Chris Waters, history (2001-04); James Nolan, sociology (2004-06); and Guy Hedreen and Elizabeth McGowan, art (2006-08).

END

For building locations on the Williams campus, please consult the map outside the driveway entrance to the Security Office located in Hopkins Hall on Main Street (Rte. 2), next to the Thompson Memorial Chapel, or call the Office of Public Affairs (413) 597-4277. The map can also be found on the web at www.williams.edu/home/campusmap/

To visit the college on the Internet: http://www.williams.edu/ Williams College can also be found on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/williamscollege and Twitter: http://twitter.com/williamscollege Event: Iliyana

END
